dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits in a middle row, doodling. The science teacher, FERRARA (40s) fires questions at the class.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARA
dialogues.text: In any ecosystem we have indigenous flora and...? Robert?

dialogues.speaker: KID, (ROBERT)
dialogues.text: Shale?

dialogues.speaker: FERRARA
dialogues.text: No, not shale...I like where you’re head’s at though... Ferrara hears Joe doodling in the otherwise silent class. Joe doesn’t notice Ferrara approaching. We see the drawin Joe, on horseback, riding into the FOREST. A girl rides w him, clutching him around the waist. He colors her dress with a YELLOW HIGHLIGHTER. Ferrara STOMPS HIS FOOT once loudly next to Joe, snapping out of his artistic trance.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joe Toy. Flora and?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning page) Fauna.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARA
dialogues.text: Very good. An allamanda cathartica would be an example of which? (off Joe’s silence) And an allamanda cathartica would be an example of which?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’ve never heard those words before in my life.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARA
dialogues.text: That was my hope. No drawing in class, please. Allamanda cathartica. Allamanda cathartica. (noticing a raised hand) Kelly. We land on KELLY (15), a pretty girl...in a YELLOW DRESS.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Flora. When Ferrara turns his back, Joe and Kelly make eye conta Joe rolls his eyes at her ass-kissing. She sticks her ton out. They’re clearly buddies. EXT. TOTTENVILLE HIGH SCHOOL - 2 P.M. School’s out. Students crowd the sidewalk. Joe walks his bicycle alongside him, keeping pace with Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: What were you drawing in there? It was obviously top secret.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh. Just some...blueprints. Patrick and me are working on this bike ramp thing.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Blueprints? Huh. That’s funny.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just don’t strike me as like a “man’s man,” y'know? Construction and all. That’s not an insult. Beat on Joe. Smiling, but insulted.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How's Patrick doing, by the way?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He's fine. I think he’s supposed to come back next week.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I was gonna say, if you guys want, you should come to Thirsty Thursdays tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: “Thirsty Thursdays.” I have no idea what that is.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: It’s a keg. At Wolf’s Pond. Paul’s friends throw it every week once it starts getting warm out and ohmygod-- The boyfriend approaches, PAUL: 17, could be 36. Goatee, earring. He’s bleeding noticeably from the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened??

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hm? Some dog bit me. I’m fine. He kisses her ‘hello’ on the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: What? For no reason??

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well I was hitting him and shit. (to Joe) What’s up man.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Oh -- Paul, you know Joe. We have Bio together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handshake) Yow.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (inspecting the wound) Should we go to the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No. You want a bagel? C’mon. I want an egg bagel.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Ugh! (to Joe) He always gets hurt, and he never goes to the doctor. Joe raises his eyebrows in false fascination.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Starving, babe.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. See you tomorrow, Joe! Joe waves, watching as Paul leads her away, shoving his h into Kelly's back pocket as they walk. Off his misery:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe rides his bike home from school. We get an impression the town: a bank, a church, a barbershop. Quaint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe steers through a narrow “trail” in the woods. It’s de with trees and brush. Craning up above the trees, we see that the woods are bordered on all sides by tracts of suburban houses. In th deep distance, factory pipes. Off the sound of a DOORBELL:  EXT. PATRICK’S HOUSE - DAY Joe waits on the stoop. The door opens to reveal MRS. MCGUIRE, 42. Patrick’s mom.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Patrick home?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Come in, Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest country-theme home. Thomas Kinkade and Precious Moments abound.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: (calling upstairs) Patrick! Joseph's here.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I’m coming down.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Stay where you are! He will come to you!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I’m fine, ma! At the top of the stairs, PATRICK MCGUIRE comes into view Though also 14, he’s a brick shithouse, a man by any phys standard. There’s an AIR CAST on his left foot. He hops down one step at a time.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Mother Cabrini, protect my son.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Stop praying, ma. Another few steps. Painstaking.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Look at you! You're sweating. You’re sweating from the pain!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I‘m sweating from you, ma. Two more stairs. He’s winded now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m getting you a cold washcloth.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I don’t want one.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Well it’s happening. How about you, Joseph? Would you like a cold washcloth?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I would take one, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No one is getting a cold washcloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On TV: “STREET FIGHTER 2” for Super Nintendo. The boys si in spitting distance of the screen, concentrating.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: My mom reminds me of Blanka.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Because she wears cutoff jeans?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No, because everything she says, in my head, sounds like Blanka’s crazy victory roar. Listen. On TV: After a knockout, BLANKA stands on his hind legs a roars three times.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s the sound I hear whenever she speaks. Just the jibberish of an undisciplined animal.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You hear that all day?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: All day. He pauses the game.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to get out of this house, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I mean I can’t stand another minute of it. Of them. They’re down my throat all day. They don’t stop.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well, you'll be back at school Monday, right? You can tough it out.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No, you don’t get it. They’re killing me. Like, I’m getting hives.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No you’re not. Patrick lifts his shirt: a few small hives are scattered his torso.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: shit.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, shit is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Family dinner. Joe sits with his father, FRANK (51), and sister LISA (19), who wears a college-team hoodie.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Daddy, can Colin come tomorrow? He really wants to meet you guys.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Can I get some sweet potato casserole? (then) Who's Colin?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: He's my boyfriend of seven months.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hm. What are his prospects? How does he plan to support you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s Sri Lankan.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Right, right. Aren’t we all. (passing food) Put that back over by you. Move the water.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Speaking of tomorrow -- can you drive me to Wolf’s Pond at like 8? Joe notices Frank staring at him in mild shock.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Thursday night, Joe. What do you think we’re sitting here talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Is this a joke? Carol is coming over Thursday. We’re having Game Night. I told you about this weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You never told me about that!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That's horseshit, Joe. I told you at least twice, and I watched you write it on your forearm in permanent marker. Joe glances at his forearm. There is some faded text.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well what if I don’t want to meet “Carol”? I don’t make you meet all the girls I bang out. Lisa snickers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This is not a debate, Joe! The plans are made. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just be there, and be pleasant. She’s making lamb stew for us. She’s going out of her way.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Lamb stew? What is this, Beowulf? I’m not touching it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Believe me, you’re touching it.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: It'll be fun, Joe. You'll get to meet Colin.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Lisa) I think I’m done hearing that name tonight, okay? Joe simmers at Frank, livid.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What, Joe. Joe rises silently and moves to the wall phone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Joe picks up the receiver and shoots Frank a threatening look.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’re supposed to be past this, Joseph! For Christ’s sake! Remember what we talked about. Think of people who really need to call 911! A moment of tension. Then, Joe opens the dishwasher, shov the phone in, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (after him) I don’t know who that’s supposed to be hurting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe watches as his friend ANGELO, 14, sticks a large FIRECRACKER into a mailbox. Angelo turns to flee.  10.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: Come on come on come on! They run across the street and hide behind some shrubs. A nebbishy kid, AARON (also 14), waits for them there. They stare at the mailbox. Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Did it light? The mailbox EXPLODES.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO / AARON
dialogues.text: Ha! Got you. / Remarkable. An INDIAN GUY, 30s, comes out and immediately spots the b

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN GUY
dialogues.text: We tired of this game yet?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: Not till you learn English, dot- head!

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN GUY
dialogues.text: Huh?? I have a double masters from Georgetown. Your father cleans pools.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: Go home! In the background, a storm door opens on one of the house A little old Italian lady pokes her head out. Angelo’S MO ANGELO’S MOM Angelo! Venire all'interno e spostare vestiti!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: Essere di destra 1a! She retreats inside.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit. I gotta go shift the wash. (to Indian guy) Fuck you, Mola Ram!!

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN GUY
dialogues.text: What?!  11.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: I’m out too. Thirsty Thursdays.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh God. You’re going to that?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Of course. Everyone’s going.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Not me. My goddam shit-eating father won’t let me. (then) And Kelly invited me too.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: So what, Kelly invited you. She's got a boyfriend. Who’s twice your size.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Right. The cave troll. What’s his name again? Ju’tuun?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Paul. I can’t believe that guy is seventeen years old. He looks like he works for Con Ed.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. (frustrated) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Well no big deal, man. There will be other...best times of your life. INT. JOE’S HOUSE, LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Game night. Lisa, Frank and Joe sit around a monopoly boa joined by COLIN, 19, bookish; and CAROL, 40, far too good this situation. Joe sits slumped, miserable.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Carol, the lamb was delicious. Very tender. It felt like I was chewing avocado meat.  12.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thanks Colin. I boil it first.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: I thought you might have. I didn’t want to presume.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Colin, no one knows what you're talking about. Carol ROLLS. Marvin Gardens.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Meh. Pass.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Passing on Marvin Gardens? Ballsy.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well look at this. I’m broke.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You pissed it all away on purples. (going through her cards) What the hell is this, Virginia? If you’re gonna rely on colors, go red, orange, yellow. Strong colors. They attract the eye. People want to land there. They will themselves to.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Royal blue. Also a fierce color.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Colin, again, we’re unclear as to what you’re saying. Joe sits up.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to this clown. His whole game is railroads. He’s got blinders on to the world.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Who’s “he”? I’m right here.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Blinders.  13.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: People need transportation, Joe. They need to get from A to B. Joe points his hands out from his temples: Blinders. He does.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Just roll, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Lisa, do you remember when you bought B&O and wouldn’t trade him, and he quit?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I didn't “quit.” I just wasn’t having fun anymore. Why would I play if I’m not having fun? What’s the point of a game? People play games to heighten life, to forget themselves.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: That's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up, Colin.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (laughing) Is that true, Frank? You actually quit Monopoly? How old are you? Frank tenses up, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, he always quits. He once quit because Lisa hit free parking six times.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Any sane person would have walked away from that game. Something wasn’t right and you goddam know it. Carol laughs, and Joe joins her. Frank shoots Joe a look. Joe shoots one back, relishing the moment of comeuppance. Frank moves his gamepiece.  14.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will absolutely buy that... (counting out money) Hello Colin.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Do you want to be my friend?

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Very badly, sir. Joe watches this exchange, not trusting it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Okay then. Right now -- Tennessee and St. James. I'’11 give you Park Place and Indiana.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Whoa whoa whoa whoa--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let the men talk, Joseph. On Joe: fuming.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Yes. Clearly, yes I would do that.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Frank, that makes no sense. He’ll kill us all.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: There will be collateral damage, yes. But war is hell. Joe looks at the board -- he sees what’s happening. His piece is in jail. Frank’s building on orange. It’s a setu

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to himself) He’s pricing me out...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (big smile) Your roll, Joey Joe-Joe.  15.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: This is bullshit, Dad! You're pricing me out of the goddam game!

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (eyeing board) Oh man...he is.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh come on Frank. He’s your son.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You can’t do that Dad! It’s collusion.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I can do whatever I want, Joe. My house, my rules. Frank lights a cigar and leans back. A suburban Bugsy. He smiles at Joe, rubbing it in. Joe’s lip quivers, but he tries not to break, tries not to give Frank the satisfact

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Let’s just have a fun game. No?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m not the one who started telling fun little, funny little stories. He’s just mad because he doesn’t want to be here, so he’s being a shit. (then) Roll the die, Joe. Let’s see what happens. If you need a loan, maybe we can work something out at a fair interest rate. A tense, miserable beat of silence. Then Joe rises, heads for the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That was a cruel thing to do, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Is he quitting? INT. JOE’S KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS Joe, red-faced, picks up the wall phone. INSERT - A switchboard operator picks up.  16.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: 911, what is your emergency? BACK IN JOE’S HOUSE: Frank knows what’s happening.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ah shit -- he’s doing it! Frank darts at Joe, but Joe runs into the bathroom and lo the door. INT. JOE’S BATHROOM —- CONTINUOUS Joe sits on the toilet, covering his ear.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (into phone) I want to report a theft...yes +..up to one thousand dollars in cash and assets...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hang it up Joe!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (into phone) 28 Rye Avenue. No, he’s actually in the house right now... Loud BANGING as Frank attempts to break the door down. Jo moves toward the corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) His name is Frank Toy, brown hair...height unknown...He’s obsessed with railroads... The door SPLINTERS. INT. JOE’S ROOM - NIGHT Through Joe’s window, we see Frank talking to two police officers. He holds the Monopoly board and makes desperate animated gestures. The officers nod. Move back to reveal Joe, watching, holding a flashlight. room is dark.  17. He shines the flashlight in short spurts out the window. dot-dot, dash-dash-dash, dot-dot-dot... After a few beats, we hear THUMPING from outside. Feet climbing stairs. Frank opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Stop signaling. Joe shines the flashlight beam into Franks’s eyes. Frank squints and shuts the door. Joe lies on the bed, miserable. He spins something around between his thumb and forefinger. Flashlight on: a small green MONOPOLY HOUSE. He looks at it, then past it, and freezes...something caught his eye. The wall across from him: Though we notice an “Excalibur” poster and other assorted nerd items, Joe’s focus is on t huge SHADOW being cast by the monopoly house. Joe regards this “house” shape... Then shines the flashlight across the room, illuminating TOOLBOX sitting atop his dresser. Beat on Joe, thinking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick enters on his boot, carrying a team duffel bag. T teacher conducts the class to recite the words on the boa

dialogues.speaker: ENTIRE CLASS
dialogues.text: Recepcidn detrds, Patrick! They applaud. Patrick smiles through the awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick recites translations, sitting by the window.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: éQué color es perros?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (with the class) Algunos perros son marrén, algunos perros son negro, algunos --  18. The sound of KNOCKING breaks his concentration -- Joe's outside, at the window. Behind him, a scrawny, olive-skin kid sits on a bicycle: BIAGGIO, 14, quiet but dedicated. Joe makes a “come here” motion. Patrick turns his palms upward in a gesture of powerlessness.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (mouthing the words) Come outside for a second. A stern Patrick points to his desk, then points to the fr of the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (mouthing) Come on. One second. Patrick writes something on loose leaf and presses it aga the window. It says “I am in school right now”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Biaggio sit on the window ledge. Patrick sees fro the corner of his eye, then shakes his head. Joe takes a sandwich out of his bag, prepared to wait it out.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Patrick, éCémo viejo es tu perro?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (caught off guard) Um, no tengo un perro, profesor. TEACHER’S VOICE Who are those boys outside? Does anyone know those boys? Are they your friends, Dudley? A black kid behind Patrick picks his head up.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Patrick’s been talking to them for five minutes, man! Why do I get blamed? TEACHER’S VOICE Because of what you are!  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick walks across the street with Joe.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Don’t do that shit anymore. You're gonna get me in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I would get detention, not you. You did nothing wrong. A car full of students drives by. A kid hanging out the window hollers “McGuire!” Patrick absently waves.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: How do you never get caught? What about the truant officer?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, the truant officer. He’s fucking 19. I'11 shit in his mouth. Cutaway to a baby faced Cop-in-a-Box idling on the curb.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (hopping on his bike) Get on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biaggio hacks through brush with a MACHETE. Joe and Patri walk the dirt path behind him.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Come on man. I can’t walk all day like this.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We’re almost there. Fifty more yards, about.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Almost where? What’s happening right now??  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The come to a large, treeless area. No civilization in sight. Joe walks to the epicenter, the about-faces and stretched his arms, like “welcome.”

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Do you want your room facing sunrise, or the sunset?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Our new house. No, “home.” We’re building a home on this very spot.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What, like a tree-house?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No, like a living-house -- I’m moving out. And I want you to come with me. Biaggio thrusts a shovel toward Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Who is this kid? (to Biaggio) Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's Biaggio.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Biaggio? What are you, an exchange student?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He’s been in our class since the 4th grade. (beat) We’ll get to him later man - are you in? Patrick rubs his eyes. Joe isn’t kidding.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You're serious about this.  21.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Of course I’m serious. Look, you can’t live with your parents, I certainly can’t live with Shit-Ass Frank any more. If we do this we can make our own rules, make our own choices! Live and die by our wits, like men! What do we need? A few 2x10s and a foundation?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: It’s not that simple, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It is, man. With my mind, and your hands, we can pull this off. We’re preternaturally skilled craftsmen.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Joe, we almost built a ramp, and I got a 92 in Shop. That doesn’t mean we can build a house!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Come on man. Break ground with me. You’re my best friend. Biaggio looks at Joe, crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Biaggio) Don’t take that to heart Biaggio. Who knows what the future holds. (to Patrick) Well? Patrick takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Look, I won’t tell anyone what you're doing, I promise. But this is insane. You know that, right? Joe's last resort:

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It’s this or the hives, man. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’1l see you later.  22. Patrick boots off into the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick jams him palm into a Heinz bottle, drizzling ketc on a burger. Mom and Dad sit on either side.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: I got the chop chuck from DeMonte’s instead of King Kullen. So the hamburgers might taste a little different. But they might taste the same. It’s fun to try new things, though.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: (to Patrick) What did Coach Locke say when he saw you?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Nothing. He just said he was glad to have me back.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: I saw your sub play last Thursday. “Moscato,” they called him.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s his last name.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: I didn’t like him. He had a weak chin. (looking at Patrick’s plate) You do that often? You eat the hamburger, then the fries? You don’t mix it up?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Patrick, have you heard about this Die Hard movie? Die Hard 5? It’s set in outer space.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Huh?  23.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Mmm...It’s not a Die Hard movie. I think it’s called Festival something.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s the one -- Festival. Bruce Die Hard is in it, though. Are you gonna go see Festival with your friends?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: “Festival.”

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Are you talking about “The Fifth Element”??

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Right! The Elements. It looks very impressive. Tell us how it is.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Did I say I was seeing it? I have no interest in it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Yes, it's with Bruce Element, and the other one, who’s the bad guy? He’s been in a lot, he's very good. “Samuel Clemens.”

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: His name is not Samuel Clemens.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Well the actor, not the character.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (rubs his eyes) I know what you mean. Samuel Clemens is Mark Twain's pen name. The actor is Gary Oldman.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Mm...no, that doesn't sound right.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Well maybe you guys should go see it! Treat yourselves. Get out of the house for a night.  24.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Maybe we will.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: (re: Patrick's food) The flavors compliment each other, if you wanted to do some of one, then some of the other.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (agitated) I know, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Your Aunt Janette is coming Friday afternoon, Patrick. I told her you'll be around. I’m going to put some cashews out.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I don’t have to call her ‘aunt’ anymore, right? I’m fourteen. She’s of no blood relation. You went to camp with her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: She loves you like an aunt, she showers you with gifts.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: She loves you, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: She gets me weird things that I don’t want. She got me a wood- burning kit.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: I know she did. And now it just sits there. Too much goes to waste in this world. Patrick just shakes his head. He bites into his burger. M McGuire can’t stop staring at Patrick’s plate.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Is that a usual thing for you, though? (to wife) He eats all of one food, and then moves onto all of another food.  25.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: So what?!

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Come on. That’s how the blind eat. We didn’t raise you to do that. To be blind.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (losing it) But how does it affect you?? Why comment on it?? Out of nowhere, Mom starts WHISTLING.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Can you whistle? Can you whistle, Patrick? I have to breath in to do it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: No no no. You’re supposed to breath out. Let the diaphragm support it. They both whistle out of key with one another. Patrick lo some color in his face and starts breathing erratically. INT. JOE'S BEDROOM/PATRICK’S BEDROOM - NIGHT The phone RINGS. Joe answers right away.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hello? Cut to Patrick’s (intercut between rooms as needed). He’s standing in front of a full length mirror, covered in HIV

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’m in.

dialogues.speaker: JOE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’m in, I said. The house. I'11 do it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (grinning) Fuckin...yes! Awesome man...okay, we break ground tomorrow at 5AM. Good shit!  26.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: How about eleven?

dialogues.speaker: JOE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Eleven’s fine. INT. KELLY’S ROOM - THE NEXT MORNING Kelly sits on her bed listening to a CD. A KNOCK on her door, then a Mom-type opens it. KELLY’S MOM Kel -- Vicki's coming up.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Okay. The best friend, VICKI (15) enters. Dark hair, dark soul.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: You’re not gonna believe this. She hands Kelly a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: ‘Architectural Digest.’ So?

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Turn to page 23. Kelly turns. We see a feature on JOE, standing before his pristine new House in the Woods.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Joe Toy??

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: He built that house with his bare hands.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Wait -- he built this??

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Well, Patrick and Biaggio helped with parts and labor, but the whole thing was Joe’s baby. God, a guy who can work with his hands... that’s the ultimate.  27.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (reading) It’s got a game room... and a botanical garden...and a lazy river!

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Ugh. He must be rich.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Rich, or just brilliant. And crafty as hell. Tight on Kelly, lost in the article.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t believe a man like this has been under my nose for a whole year. We hear more KNOCKING. It seems to come from far away...

dialogues.speaker: SOUNDBRIDGE TO
dialogues.text: INT. JOE’S SHOWER - REAL LIFE, 10AM The knocking snaps Joe out of his DAYDREAM. He’s showerin His hair is sculpted into a shampoo mohawk.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Joe! You’ve been in there for fifty-five minutes! INT. JOE’S HOUSE, UPSTAIRS HALLWAY - MOMENTS LATER Frank waits outside the door, messy and unshaven. The wat turns off. He knocks again. INT. JOE’S BATHROOM —- CONTINUOUS Joe brushes his teeth. He shoots a contemptuous glance at the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Let’s go. I have a tee time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank knocks again.  28.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You have to talk to me eventually, Joe. Silence. After a beat, Joe runs out, naked and still soak His hands are cupped over his genitals.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (averting his eyes) Jesus. As Joe scampers into his room:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’ve gotta bring underwear in with you, Joe! You're 14 years old! It’s not cute anymore! EXT. JOE’S NEIGHBORHOOD - DAY Bird's eye of Joe bursting out of his side gate on his bi We move up and over the rooftops, heading past subdivisio strip malls, until the woods appear in the distance. We m in until treetops fill the frame. We linger on the dense green tableau. It could be anywhere in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick, Joe and Biaggio stand in a large rectangular hol the earth, DIGGING. Judging by the stains and general demeanor, the fun part is over. We hear grunts, wheezing.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to Biaggio) Did you talk to your father about concrete?

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: He says it’s impossible, and he says if I ask again he’s going to throw my binder in the garbage.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (stops shoveling) Well shit man, where does that leave us?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Relax, we’ll think of a substitute. We could use sod, we could use clay, we--  29.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: This isn’t the fucking French Open, Joe! We need a concrete foundation. That’s like rule one.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: We could use dirt. Pack it hard.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You want to fill this hole with dirt? Biaggio shrugs. Patrick throws his shovel and climbs out the hole.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Relax man! This is a flawed process.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (climbing) No shit. Call me when you have some idea what’s going on.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: C'mon, keep your eye on the prize here! We need you, Tum Tum!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: And we're not using nicknames from “Three Ninjas,” either. Patrick is gone. Biaggio starts after him, but Joe stops him.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Let him go, Colt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe walks in, utterly filthy. The door chimes. Guy behind the counter:

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Not cool, guys. I just had the floors buffed yesterday. By the refrigerators, Patrick, also very filthy, browses drinks. Joe approaches.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How can I make you happy here?  30.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (hands Joe a Snapple) First, you’re gonna buy me a Guava Mania. Second, I want you to make a fucking plan! Read a book!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hey man, I never said it would be easy, I just said it would be worth it. Good things come to those who wait. Friends are the best therapy.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’ve been to your house, asshole! Those are your refrigerator magnets. Patrick moves up an aisle. Joe follows.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Fine. I'11 do some research, okay? We both will. Patrick hands Joe a box of frozen waffles.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: These are coming too. (back on subject) I’ve done the research, Joe! Did you know that pine cones are a legitimate source of fiber? That the red baneberry is edible, but the white one is deadly? That skunk spray can blind you? No, you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (sigh) Yes, fine, you know things. But no one learns as much from books as they do from actual real life, okay? You can bring a fucking meat thermometer and your Cub Scout manual if you want, but at some point we’re gonna have to dick up and trust our instincts.. ATTENDANT’S VOICE Yo! Out of the store! Not gonna say it again!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (ignoring attendant) Joe, all I'm saying is, let’s do this right. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not in the mood for another Joe Toy disaster.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Fine, yes, agreed. That’s all I’m saying too. (beat) So you’re still on board?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Look at me. I’m on board. Joe exhales, relieved. Patrick throws a bag of pork rinds Joe's pile.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These too.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Wow. You’re a class act.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: MONTAGE. MUSIC CUE: “WHITE WINTER HYMNAL” by FLEET FOXES Joe plucks books from LIBRARY SHELVES. He stacks them on checkout counter: “WALDEN.” “105 OUTDOOR RECIPES.” “SO, Y WANT TO BUILD A CABIN.” Blueprints unroll. Reveal Joe, Patrick and Biaggio review them in an empty classroom. It feels like a war room. In the woods, Joe and Biaggio dump piles of timber next t Patrick, who ties them together with small vines. They ar symphony of sweat and grime. Joe and Biaggio watch as Patrick confidently bites into a herb. There’s an open reference book in Patrick’s hand. Joe stacks more books at the library counter: “SELF RELIA AND OTHER ESSAYS.” Then, the following comic books: “SPAW “BATMAN VS. PREDATOR,” “SUPERMAN: CAMELOT FALLS.” Then another reference book, “I'D RATHER BE HUNTING.” Patrick messes around with some dry twigs and flint, tryi to get a spark. Once he does, he blows on it - FIRE. On a suburban street, Biaggio halts his bike, seeing something. Swoosh pan to a sofa left on the curb as trash Biaggio and Joe set the sofa on a lumpy wood floor -- the house in the woods. One wall has been erected. On his stoop, Patrick picks leaves, twigs off his jeans a scatters them in the garden. He keeps an eye on the door.  32. Joe sits on the toilet, reading his Superman comic. Biaggio rides his bike through an affluent neighborhood. stops and looks off camera, in awe of something... Joe and Biaggio, guided by Patrick, carry an enormous POO SLIDE, ladder included. As the inch closer to the “house, we see that three walls have been erected, and there is m garbage furniture than before. It’s getting there. Joe emerges from a thick bit of trees and finds himself a a decent sized cliff, maybe seventy feet high. Out in fro of him, treetops stretch for miles. He inhales. END MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Patrick sit at an empty lunch table, drinking pla quarter drinks.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do about parents?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well I’m not leaving a note or anything. I’m gonna let him stew in it for a while. Patrick makes a face, reacting to Joe’s harshness.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What happened in your house the other night anyway, man?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nothing. He’s just...it’s like the chicken or the egg with my Dad. I don’t know if he’s alone because he’s a dick, or if he’s a dick because he’s alone. But either way he’s a dick. And he’s alone. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s scary.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah it is...what if I wound up like my Dad. Jesus -- what if I wound up like my Mom??  33.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She’s a strange bird.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I had a dream like maybe two days ago that she took a Polaroid of me on the toilet, and then ate it before it could develop.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oof. I feel like that’s dense with meaning.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah. Patrick chugs a purple quarter drink.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I had a dream that I could talk to reef sharks.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What did the sharks say?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: They didn’t speak so much as rap. Joe drinks. Patrick gazes across the lunchroom.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (sentimental) I‘ll miss this stuff a little.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, a little. Joe's POV: A table across the room. A bunch of girls in matching T- shirts, part of the Spring Musical Committee. He’s focuse on one glittered face, laughing with her friends: Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To establish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick sits awake on his bed. On edge.  34. Then, his BEEPER goes off. He picks up a cordless phone. INT. JOE’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS Joe's beeper goes off. He silences it, then moves to his closet. He takes out two overstuffed DUFFEL BAGS. INT. PATRICK’S PARENTS’ ROOM - NIGHT Patrick watches his folks sleep. The house feels like a w safe place right now -- now that he’s leaving. He kisses his hand, and touches the door, but remains composed. His parents don’t stir. INT. JOE’S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Frank sleeps on the sofa, lit by blue light from the TV. Joe observes with narrow eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe rides, weighed down by duffels and equipment. Patrick rides on the pegs, holding his own luggage. WIDE. They take in the ‘burbs for a final time. The stree are dimly lit, desolate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe walks his bike into the woods, but Patrick stares bac the direction they came, hesitant.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You coming?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah...This is happening, huh?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It is. Patrick tries to articulate things.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’ve never done anything like this in my entire life, man.  35.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (walks to his side) Sometimes when I’m about to make a big decision, I say “I will go through with this unless God gives me a very definite omen within the next 30 seconds.” We could do that.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Okay. Let’s do that. They stand silent for the agreed interval, each in his ow thoughts. Then, a clap of THUNDER. Patrick furrows a brow

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Okay, time. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: That’s thunder, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s thunder. (points at shit) That’s a tree, that’s a rock. It’s nature. It’s not an omen. He walks into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C’mon. Patrick steels himself.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Jesus. This is happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TORRENTIAL RAIN. The boys are soaked. The trees overhead can only do so much. They negotiate the path in silence. Patrick is not smilin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in. Snippets of the house are revealed in FLASHLIGHT BEAMS. A piece of junky furniture...a portion makeshift wall...the water-slide in the room’s center...  36. INT. HOUSE IN THE WOODS, “UPSTAIRS” - NIGHT Darkness. Joe throws Patrick his used towel, then unrolls sleeping bag.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (drying off) Where's Biaggio?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I haven't heard from him in 3 days. But every instinct in my body tells me he’s already up here.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here. Gimme the flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You’re not gonna like the outcome of this. Patrick shines the flashlight around the room.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I feel like he’d be right next to you. Patrick turns the beam to his immediate left and, sure enough, Biaggio stares back at him, a ghastly figure. Patrick SCREAMS. Soundbridge to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MORNING BELL, over an establishing shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Series of shots in various classrooms: A) Spanish class. The teacher reads from an attendance bo

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH TEACHER
dialogues.text: Lacertosa? (check) Laffin? (check) McGuire? Nothing. We see an empty seat.  37.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH TEACHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: McGuire? B) History class.

dialogues.speaker: HISTORY TEACHER
dialogues.text: Toy? Joe Toy? C) English.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH TEACHER
dialogues.text: Anyone hear from Joseph Toy? D) Concert Band.

dialogues.speaker: BAND TEACHER
dialogues.text: Patrick McGuire here? McGuire? The teacher looks to an empty seat in the trombone sectio

dialogues.speaker: BAND TEACHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think you can handle first trombone today? A young trombonist slides into Patrick’s chair.

dialogues.speaker: TROMBONIST
dialogues.text: I think so, John.

dialogues.speaker: BAND TEACHER
dialogues.text: Once again people, we do not call teachers by their first names. E) Health class.

dialogues.speaker: HEALTH TEACHER
dialogues.text: Toy? H) Gym.

dialogues.speaker: GYM TEACHER
dialogues.text: McGuire? (silence) Okay...Miller? (check) Moscato? Cut to Moscato raising his hand. He does have a weak chin A phone RINGS... INT. MCGUIRE HOUSE, BEDROOM --— DAY A hand shoots into frame; Mrs. McGuire’s.  38.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello, parent of (human voice) -- “Patrick McGuire” -- this is Tottenville High School calling to inform that your child was absent from one or more scheduled classes, and will require a written note -- She hangs up. Reveal her laying in bed. It seems as thoug she’s been there a bit. The door opens. Mr. McGuire peeks in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: It was just the school.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Okay. If you want to come down...the police seem optimistic. She nods and rolls over, despondent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. McGuire at the table, sifting through photos of Patri with a PLAIN CLOTHES detective. Behind them, CAPTAIN ARTY DAVIS (50s) looks around.

dialogues.speaker: PLAIN CLOTHES
dialogues.text: Wrestler, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Yes. A good one.

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DAVIS
dialogues.text: (delicate) Did you notice if Patrick had been running with any new friends? A different group than usual? Anyone give you a bad feeling?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: No. He had good friends. He was popular, people liked him... He stares into space.  39.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My wife would know more about that. I don’t know if she...it’s just the shock of it.

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DAVIS
dialogues.text: Honestly, I see a lot of these, and you guys are doing great. You’re a tough bunch. Mr. McGuire tries to smile.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Thank you...it’s... (pause) He’s our only son, is the thing. He’s our only child, so...you’1l get him back?

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DAVIS
dialogues.text: We'll get him back. INT. JOE’S HOUSE, KITCHEN - NIGHT Frank, alone at the table. He rubs his finger around the edge of his glass of scotch, making a whistling sound. LISA’S VOICE Daddy? Frank moves to the doorway; Lisa and Colin walk through t storm door with some bags packed. She hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Shhh. It’s okay. I’m sure he’s fine. Colin awkwardly rubs her back. INT. JOE’S ROOM - LATER Frank & Lisa search Joe’s room, go through doors, check t closets.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We don’t know much. The thing is...(pause) Some things are missing. Things Joe might have planned to take. All his clothes. The Monopoly. The spare from the Avalon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...he ran away?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s still mostly guesswork, Li... But yes, it looks that way. Colin comes to the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: The Chinese food is here, Mr. Toy. It's fifty-one dollars.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (digging into pocket) Fifty-one dollars? What did you order Lisa!?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Nothing. I got dumplings. I’m not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: I got us a big order of shrimp with lobster sauce. I figured it’s neutral.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Neutral? Shrimp with lobster sauce? I can’t think of a more marginal dish in any culture.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I thought it was neutral. I thought we could all enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Come on Colin, no one’s gonna eat that! Now there’s gonna be a pint of hot cum in my refrigerator for a week. Use your head next time. Colin takes the money and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Be nice to him, Dad. Please. He wants to help.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Colin’s feelings are not a priority right now. Sorry. 40.  4l.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I know...but you don’t have to be Mean, Daddy You just... Lisa assigns blame as gently as possible.

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t have to always be so mean. You know?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Am I mean to you?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: No. But I’m like the only one, Dad. Frank contemplates this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few students pause to acknowledge... A MISSING CHILD poster. It’s a collage of three pictures: Patrick in his wrestling gear; Patrick posing with his parents in front of the globe at EPCOT; Patrick’s tastefu class photo. Off an image of Patrick’s INNOCENT FACE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick pulls his new, BEARDED face out of the fresh wate Reveal him sitting at the edge of a pond.

dialogues.speaker: JOE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Patrick! He looks -- Joe and Biaggio stand on a high rock, holding tire attached to a rope. Joe has also grown wispy facial hair. Biaggio wears a swimming cap and underwear. Joe swings. He lets go at the top of his arc and cannonba into the water. As he emerges:

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Ehhh...six.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (genuine disappointment) Six...Godammit.  Joe swings the tire back up to Biaggio.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Why does he have a swimming cap, but no bathing suit? 42. Biaggio clutches the tire and surveys the stream, nervous

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (cups hands to mouth) Biaggio, just let go when you get to the top! It’s not even deep!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Look at this. He’s terrified.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I know. He once told me he’s only afraid of two things -- drowning, werewolves, very old music, and homeless women who can run or jump.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: That’s four things.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’m telling you exactly what he told me. Biaggio swings, all four limbs wrapped around the tire. At the top of his swing, he does nothing, paralzed with fear He swings back and forth, losing momentum.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What are you, a cat? Let go!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We're here Biaggio! We won't let the river claim you! Biaggio drops his legs. They enter the water at the knee. His hands are still fused to the tire. He hangs there.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay...we’re sort of in no man’s land here, Biaggio! Just make a decision! We want to use the tire!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Just untie it.  43.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Did you hear that, Biaggio? I’m giving you one more chance to do this on your terms! Biaggio lets go and falls awkwardly into the stream.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick stands in front of a beat-up mirror, shirtless... His hives are gone. He breathes deep, flexes, grins. He feels like himself. Then, ending his moment of serenity:

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yo. We have a food situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe gets downstairs via the WATER SLIDE from earlier. As walks through the house, we reveal it in its entirety: The water slide leads up to a “loft” area (just a huge le where the guys sleep. Downstairs, we recognize some garba furniture from earlier scenes -- a sofa, a lamp. There’s a dining room: an AIR HOCKEY TABLE. As Patrick and Joe approach this corner, Biaggio leans ov the table counting grains of rice.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to Patrick) No more rice. And no more pasta. It’s time. Joe starts rummaging through a pile of supplies, emerging with a souvenir SWORD.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What kind of game are we dealing with?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Deer, pheasant, rabbit. You might run into a lynx.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Any bison? Cougar? Anything real?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You’re gonna kill a buffalo with a sword you got from a gift shop in Colonial Williamsburg?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It’s not the size of the blade, but the will of the swordsman.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (rolls eyes) You gotta stop with that elf shit, man. Joe re-sheathes his weapon.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Okay. Biaggio and I will hunt. You gather.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Then...here, take these. Patrick hands Joe and Biaggio small cardboard MASKS with crude FACES drawn on them in magic marker. Patrick wears his, but on the BACK OF HIS HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointing to it) It's so animals don’t pounce on you from behind.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (regarding masks) This one’s supposed to be me?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Whatever man. I wasn’t going for accuracy. Joe puts his on.  45.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So an animal will see this and think I’m looking at him, and walking backwards, and that all my joints are backwards.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: It works, Joe. Nigerian bushmen have been doing it for centuries.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Right, Nigerian bushmen. And we all know how great they turned out.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What does that mean? Joe turns around with his mask on. Then he sticks his han out behind him, toward Patrick, as if offering a handshak

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hey, nice to meet you. I’m Joe.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Fuck yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide shot, to establish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick holds open a field guide, checking the bunch of r berries before him against an illustration. He plucks them, bites into one for confirmation...then to the bunch into a bucket with other berries, roots, herbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe carries his sword, Biaggio his machete. They look lik little murderers.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I want to thank you for helping us, Biaggio. A lot of people would have just stayed in the comfort of their homes.  46.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: This is life experience. Both my grandfathers went to war. My father lived among the bees. This is what I’1l have done.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Exactly! It’s our rite of passage, goddamit. (deep, satisfied breath) I mean have you ever felt this at one with the natural world, with your instincts? This masculine?

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I don’t really see myself as “having a gender.” (then) Is that bad?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I mean, it’s not great. The boys duck through a thick, gnarly patch of brush... To find CIVILIZATION. The woods have ended. They stare at strip mall across the street. A BOSTON MARKET looms, the crown jewel of the shopping center.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: (staring) Is it real?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yes, it is... (then) Let’s go. We’re moving on. Biaggio is still entranced.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: The 1/4 dark is very good, though.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Sure it is. You don’t think I know that? It falls off the goddam bone. But Boston Market, that’s not roughing it, that’s not living by our wits. That’s not the man’s code, the code of the forest.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: One day, maybe.  47.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yes, sure, one day. C’mon man, this was a test, and we passed. JOE'S POV: a B.M. employee throws garbage in a side dumps Close on Joe as he gets an idea.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hmm...hold my weapon, Biaggio... Joe darts across the street. A moving car WIPES THE FRAME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nearly-clean chicken skeleton falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: JOE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Cut it right here. Reveal Joe and Biaggio rigging a TRAP: The chicken is tied to a stick, which props up an overtur WHEELBARROW. In theory, it should work.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Look at this bait, man. Biaggio looks at the chicken carcass. Flies buzz around i

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Are there bears in these woods?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I hope to God there are. A bear would feed us for a month... Joe looks at the wheelbarrow.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He'd be too big for the trap...but I think we could at least disillusion him. A bear who doesn’t believe in anything is easier to bring down.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Have you ever eaten a bear steak?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (fiddling with the trap) No. You?  48.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Once. At my sister’s communion. Joe flicks the line.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well it’s just a waiting game now, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick shakes the shit out of an APPLE TREE. Granny smit rain down. He bends to pick one up, and something catches his eye... He grabs a twig and pokes at the ground, finally lifting very long, very appalling

dialogues.speaker: SNAKESKIN
dialogues.text: He regards it with fear and revulsion. Then chucks it int the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Biaggio play RUMMY, cards fanned out before them.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wonder, we bury fruit seeds, and new fruit grows. We bury what is left, and it’s reborn.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Could that not work with people? Bury the remains, the vital organs, and a new one might grow?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I don’t think it’s a bad theory, but we've been burying the dead for thousands of years, and that has never happened.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hm; valid point. (then) Rummy.  49.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (inspecting) You only have five cards here. Sudden SOUNDS OF A STRUGGLE from the woods behind them. T trap is sprung.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit! Yes! Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear awful SCRATCHING and SQUEALING from inside. They approach, sick with fear.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (sword at the ready) Okay, turn the thing.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Turn the thing...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah just turn the wheelbarrow. Just, you know..flip it, and I, uh, will take its life.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Okay. (moves to wheelbarrow) Strike at the neck. Don’t compromise the meat.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I know...I know... Biaggio puts his hands on the wheelbarrow.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: You want this on your hands?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What choice do we have?! We need to eat goddammit...

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: It may plead. Don’t listen. Be cold, clinical with the blade.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Okay, okay.  50.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: It may try to bargain. This is natural. You must--

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Turn the fucking thing over! He does: A huge pink and white POSSUM, likely rabid, hiss at Joe. The boys SCREAM. INSERT: Wide above the forest. Their screams echo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three whole roasted chickens sizzle on a SPIT, pulled ove crackling fire.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I guess I’m surprised you found live chicken in these woods.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Why should that be surprising? Chicken outnumber people in this world. You’re an educated guy, I don’t need to tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just had never seen one in Staten Island, New York before.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well that’s crazy. There was a time when you hadn’t seen me yet, right? Did that mean I didn’t exist?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I don’t even know what the fuck we're talking about any more.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter. Biaggio, your creamed spinach is to die for. Biaggio nods.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You guys should know I found a copperhead skin by the creek. It definitely belonged to a mature adult. In the event--  51.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: C’mon man. We’re having a nice meal.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: This is important Joe!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: There’s always something with you. Some doom and gloom.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: It’s not doom and gloom, Joe, it’s the reality of living in the goddam forest, which was your idea to begin with.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: The thing...it has venom?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yes. Listen -- (to both) If you see it, stay calm. They respond to fear.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: I read once that animals see fear as a color.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I thought you couldn’t read?

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: I can read. I can’t cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Patrick sit on rocks, looking out.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Doesn’t suck, does it.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No. No it doesn’t. Reverse to their POV: Trees. Stars. Peaceful. (We might remember this view from the earlier montage) Joe flips his BACKPACK around and unzips it.  52.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I was saving these... He removes a SIX PACK.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For the right moment.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (happily accepting) No shit.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yes shit. They clank bottles and drink. Their first beer together.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah...Do you feel it?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Feel what.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We’re doing it, man. We have shelter, water, the means to put food on the table. We’re totally self-reliant. We just grew up. (then) We're men now. Men.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Just now? It just happened?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It happened man. Cheers. Joe takes another pull. Patrick shakes his head, bemused.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now all we need is the Ham.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What’s the ‘ham?’

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The Ham. You know, the Ham -- the pussy.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No, I don’t know “the ham, the pussy.” Where the fuck did you get that from?  53.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It’s in the culture.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: We're in the same culture. I’ve never heard that.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The Ham! We takin’ a ride in the HAMbulance, to HAMsterdam! Uh!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Are you done?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I am. (swig) I’m just saying, if something were missing from this, that would be it. (then) A woman’s touch. He drinks, suddenly distant. We know who he’s thinking about... He hears a sqeak, and notices a SQUIRREL peering at him. reaches into his coat and tosses it a NUT, or some tasty morsel. It grabs the nut and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The squirrel runs with its prize, over rocks and roots. I pauses at the base of a tree and begins to nibble. Suddenly, we hear HISSING, and the rustling of leaves. It freezes...and turns to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-million dollar home. Chrysler New Yorker in the driveway. Basketball hoop out front. Frank stares at it, chewing gum nervously. He’s shaven, pressed, more put together than we’ve ever seen. He takes a deep breath, and goes halfway up the walk...th doubles back toward his car.  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts the engine. Then kills it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to himself) Fuck you! Pussy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rings the bell. Waits. An attractive, middle-aged brunette answers. She’s taken aback to see Frank there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Clarissa. INT. CLARISSA’S KITCHEN - DAY They sit over coffee. Opposite sides of the table.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Had you guys been fighting?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He called 911 over a Monopoly game.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: See, I don’t like that. That’s a regression. Twin 19 year-olds, JOSH and JAKE, enter and raid the frid

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Ma, Denise is coming over later.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Fine. Just clean the basement. Without provocation, Jake backhands his brother in the crotch. Josh doubles over, mostly in shock.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Dick'd ya!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh! Dick’d ya! Josh chases Jake into the living room. Clarissa sighs.  55.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I guess they don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: No, they know. (then) So, what? The police came?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it doesn’t...I mean, all we do is fight, Clarissa.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Boys and their fathers clash, Frank. It’s normal. (then) You didn’t get along with your father for decades, right? And now you love and respect him dearly.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, because he’s dead. (takes a sip) Joe wasn’t always like this. This angry, this moody. Frank stirs his drink. Uncomfortable silence.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: If you try to put this on me, the conversation is over.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m not putting anything on you. I’m just saying. He’s difficult.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Every teenager is moody.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah. One time we had a fight over his grades. He told me my mother “sucked cocks in hell.”

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: He did not say that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Verbatim.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSA
dialogues.text: Hm...it’s from The Exorcist though. It’s not his original thought.  56.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I think we can agree it’s not the number one thing to say about your grandmother. Silence. She can’t argue that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gonna say something, because it has to be said. And you have to hear it. (then) I think if you came back, Joe would too. There it is. Clarissa nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stands facing the door, as it slams. He stands ther for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School’s out. AARON waves goodbye to some friends, and breaks away. He walks alone down the a street behind the school bleachers. The other side of the street is woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe’s POV: Aaron, through trees.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Psst! No response.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Psssst! Aaron keeps walking, content in whatever he’s thinking ab Joe picks up a rock and chucks it without aiming. It hits Aaron just above the eye and ricochets out of frame. Aaron moans and drops to one knee. He looks around, confu and in pain, putting up a desperate hand to ward off furt attacks.  57.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: shit. He checks the street -- empty. Then runs toward Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron, staring at it, awed. Joe smiles, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: No fucking way. Patrick emerges from the house, big grin.

dialogues.speaker: AARON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hal Aaron and Patrick exchange a huggy, slappy, greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron pokes and prods at the housewares, fascinated. Biag sits at a barrel, sorting berries by color. Patrick watch over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Make yourself at home, man. You thirsty? Hungry? Joe reaches for the apple bowl, tosses one to Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Joe...how did you do this? How long did it take?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: About ten days. It’s a pretty simple structure. The roof is plywood, it just rests there...you could flap it open if you wanted to...I handled schematics...Patrick bound most of the walls together... Joe looks around. A moment of pride for the accomplishmen

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, it’s a start. Eventually we'll add to it. We’re just still getting used to the family dynamic. But we have ideas for the place. We've talked about a garden. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know Biaggio desperately wants a dog.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: It’s all I dream about.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yes, but why do you want a dog? Biaggio looks down.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, he can’t answer that. That’s what troubles us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron follows Joe down a path.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I need a ride to Thirsty Thursdays tonight. Can you take me?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: My brother's driving. But yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Your brother? I thought he was like nineteen.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: He was when you met him, yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He won’t make me out, will he?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Please. My brother’s a fucking idiot. He couldn’t find his asshole with his finger. (then) Not that he’d want to. Not that anyone would.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Whatever. I’11l be there. I have to talk to Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Shit man -- she came up to me last week asking if I had heard anything about you guys. It honestly looked like she was crying. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: AARON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like she had just finished. She was flush about the cheeks. And her very tasteful mascara was a little runny. Joe processes the information. This shit is on.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’1l be outside the Greenville Boston Market. Do not forget. INT. AARON’S KITCHEN - EVENING Aaron sits at dinner with his brother ERIC, 23, a young m with no sideburns. Aaron’s MOM is at the stove.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Eric, can you give one of my friends a ride to Wolf's?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: If he got gas money. (to their mother) Where’s meat? AARON’S MOM This is beef stew. It’s a specific type of meat. What have I said about speaking in generalities?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Fine. (looking around) When’s man coming home? AARON’S MOM Your father is in Atlantic City. He is also a very specific type of man, he is your Fa-Ther. Aaron’s mom brings over a cauldron of beef stew. AARON’S MOM (CONT'D) Now this is piping, piping hot, alright? Don’t touch it for a good ten minutes. Eric immediately ladles a heaping portion into his plate.  60. AARON’S MOM (CONT'D) I’m not kidding, Eric. I know you’re hungry, but look at it. It’s still boiling. Eric takes a bite and instantly spits it back into his pl with a wet THUD. He exhales, and then lifts the food to h mouth again. AARON’S MOM (CONT'D) Fine. Burn your mouth for Easter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe wears a hooded sweatshirt, a hat, shades. He paces, fidgets. Like a wanted man. Then, the sound of speakers rattling with too much bass. turns to see an ancient two-door CAMARO pull into the par lot. This is Eric’s princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Aaron in back, Eric and some guido friend up fron Obnoxious TECHNO music plays. Deafening. EXT. WOLFE’S POND PARK - NIGHT They walk down a path, walled in by tall grass. Distant sounds of a party, and faint orange firelight. Joe and Aa lag behind the older guys.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: What if someone recognizes you?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If anyone makes eye contact with me, I’m gone. If they ask you, deny everything. EXT. WOLFE’S POND PARK, BEACH - NIGHT They're at “Thirsty Thursdays,” a raging, lively keg. Mus a bonfire, a huge keg line, teenagers grinding up on each other. Fun. Joe walks along the outer edge of the general party area, keeping his head low, but taking it in. Shit, if his life had been anything like this...  61.

dialogues.speaker: KEG
dialogues.text: Kelly’s goth pal VICKI comes down from a keg-stand. The guys holding her legs turn out to be Eric and his friend. Vicki looks at Eric, who smiles like a creep.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Joe hides behind someone’s pickup, scanning the scene...s no sign of Kelly. Suddenly he hears a SCREAM from behind him: And there she is, by the water. She’s surrounded by dudes with backwards hats. One of the guys has her around the waist. They toss her, screaming, into the bay. Laughter. She emerges, yelling and splashing at them. Tight on Joe. Suddenly, two hands land on Joe’s shoulders and whip him around. A BLONDE KID is staring him in the face.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE KID
dialogues.text: Dude! Where you been?? He pulls the hood down, revealing Joe’s face. Joe’s eyes dart around, but he’s trying to keep it cool.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, you’re not Doug. Sorry bro.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Uh, it’s okay. All good. The kid stumbles away, wasted.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE KID
dialogues.text: Yeah man. My fault. Nice face though... Joe turns to look at himself in the car window, and wince Unkempt, wispy beard. General filthiness.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Shit. A hand reaches for the car door he’s standing in front of He turns to see a dripping-wet Kelly.  62.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. (eyes widen, realizing) OhmyGod!! Joe covers her mouth. EXT. WOLFE’S POND PARK, PLAYGROUND - NIGHT Joe and Kelly alone, on a SEESAW. We hear party sounds in the distance, and lapping waves.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: But why not like, run away to California?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: This was the only way to start fresh on our own terms. We answer to no one. We don’t need a larger social structure to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (laughing) Oh my God! You went insane!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Or we're the only sane ones.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Well either way. I wouldn’t have the guts to do it. Joe beams at the compliment. Kelly takes a drink from her big red solo cup.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, um...can I see it?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I mean, that’s funny. The reason I’m out here, risking the entire enterprise, was to invite you over for dinner. If you want.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Obviously “I want.” How do I get there? Do I have to be blindfolded?  She makes 63.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure yet. And it is of absolute vital importance that you not tell anyone, not bring anyone, not breathe a word of this conversation or any ensuing events, to anyone, no best friends, no family. No one.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Okay. Can I bring Vicki?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (beat) Fine. Just Vicki.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Oh my God. So much fun. Does Patrick have a big crazy beard too?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, a little more serious than this one. I have thin hair. A gift and a curse.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Facial hair is very sexy. You just gotta, you know, groom it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Right, like Paul. a face.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I guess you wouldn’t have heard... Paul and I broke up.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No, I didn’t get wind of it. It’s not big news among the badgers. (then) I’m sorry, though. Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (bemused) Yes, I’m very okay. Thank you. A silhouetted figure calls to them, backlit by headlights  64. KID’S VOICE Yo Kel! We’re leaving!

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Shit. Okay. When am I coming?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Saturday. KID’S VOICE (walking toward them) Who is that?!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (panic) I’m out of here.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Go! I’1l see you Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Bring your appetite. And some insect repellent. (running off) Oh, hey -- yellow is your favorite color, right?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Yes...why? But he’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick walks outside, groggy.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
