dialogues.text: Patrick brushes his teeth with boiled water from the pot, over the fire. He looks up, and notices Biaggio, about twenty yards away, clinging to a tree, perfectly still. He stares at Patrick. He is covered with mud, leaves and branches, trying to be camouflaged.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Biaggio. No response. Patrick moves toward him.  65.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yo. I see you man. He’s now a foot from Biaggio’s face. Biaggio won’t break.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello! I fucking see you! I’m looking in your eyes! Biaggio stares back unfazed, at one with the tree.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dickhead! Fed up, he pushes Biaggio off the tree..

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Oh, hey. What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (rolls eyes) Yeah, “hey.” Where’s Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe picks yellow flowers in a vast meadow. Joe, half submerged in a stream, trims his facial hair. Joe lays out clothing options. There are three shorts-and T-shirt combinations. All are stained and grimy. “Upstairs,” Joe unrolls a blanket, revealing small safe deposit box. He unlocks it and removes a wad of PETTY CAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, and his new MOUSTACHE, sets the table with hot Bosto Market Chicken.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (from doorway) Such hypocrisy.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What? This is a special occasion.  66.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Bullshit man. How much chicken have you bought since we got here??

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Huh? I mean, maybe one or two along the way. Biaggio and I have been pretty goddam dangerous out there.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (sigh) I can live with the chicken being store-bought, but I’m disappointed in the loaded potato. I thought that was really Biaggio’s recipe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That actually really is. I have no idea where he’s getting chives. Patrick looks at Joe’s moustache.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: And I’d lose that thing as well.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What? (realizing) Nope. This is who I am now.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You look fucking weird, man. You look like one of those kids who works in the student Shop Rite.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You don’t know what you’re talking about. The moustache is the real man’s choice. It’s a companion.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: It’s not a real moustache. It’s all stringy and pervy.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Give it some time.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (staring at it) You look like that kid Mike Mancuso.  67.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Mancuso? He’s a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: He brought a flare gun to school in January. Remember that?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What do you want me to tell you? January’s tough on some people.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Seriously, shave the moustache.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe staring into the fire. The wavy heat lines gliss to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crane down from an immaculate sunset. Joe and Kelly watch wearing huge, flowing, Arthurian robes. Flower pedals fal from the sky. A land of kings and wizards.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How do you like it here?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: This is the happiest I’ve ever been, Joe. But... (looks at him) Are we too young to know what love is?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I know. I’m afraid of that too. But we can be afraid together. He leans in to kiss her, when:

dialogues.speaker: PAUL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Kelly. They turn - Paul waits by edge of the trees. He looks haggard, crazed.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Time to come home.  68.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I am home.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Cut the shit, babe! You’re fifteen, I’m seventeen. Time to settle down.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Not with you, Ju’tuun. Never with you. She clutches Joe’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me. This? This...boy??

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: He’s more man than you’ll ever be. End this, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: “End this”...are you sure you know what you're asking? She nods. Then, Paul unsheathes two large, wrought-iron hookswords CHARGES. In one fluid motion, Joe jumpkicks Kelly out of way, and slices a ROPE running along the floor. Joe then rolls, as we see a huge LOG, hanging by a thick rope, swi out from the trees behind them. Paul turns -- it hits him in the chest, obliterating him the cliff. He bounces a few times along the rocky face, a then slides to a halt, dead. Joe and Kelly peer down at him. She begins to cry gently.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You would weep for him?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Only for youth...only for youth. Some weasels approach the corpse and begin to pick at it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The animals will take his eyes...denying his entry into Paradise... He kisses her forehead, then stares across the treetops, reflecting on the fragile nature of life.  69.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Joe! As Joe turns around:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe snaps out of it, turning to face Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: We have company. Aaron, Vicki and Kelly emerge from the trail behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelly in the doorway, seeing everything for the first tim

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me right now? From Kelly’s POV: The slide, the hockey table, the loft. waits nervously for her judgment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is great, Joe! On Joe’s face. Life is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Boston Market feast. The sunflowers Joe picked sit in t center of the table.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: I like your beard, Patrick! You look like a werewolf.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: (quick, to Vicki) Watch your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: What did you guys do with this chicken? Garlic? Oil? Rosemary?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Biaggio?  70.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Thyme. Garlic and oil. Lotta pepper. Patrick rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: It melts. You don’t need a knife.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: What do you guys eat most of the time? This?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah. There are a lot of chicken in these woods, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Patrick takes care of berries, grains, herbs.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Ha. You’re like an Australopithecus woman.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I handle meats, proteins. I usually do the hunting.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (quiet) And the shopping. Joe glares at him. Patrick smiles, mouth full, loving it.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: What do you do, Biaggio?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Biaggio’s a renaissance man. He belongs out here. And such quick hands. He can snatch trout right out of the creek.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: It’s true man. I’ve seen it.  71. Biaggio slides something across the table to Aaron: a wal Aaron checks the inside; it’s his.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Did you take anything out?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: He doesn’t want your money. He does it for sport. Joe notices Kelly eyeing the flowers. Good. She points at them.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Aaron, can you pass me the corn? Aaron complies, handing them to her over the flowers. Joe registers the slightest disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Kelly. She points at a wall: half a rotten fish skeleton nailed above a calendar. Beneath that, an old wi legged stool.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: What’s this supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: This is the den.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Ha. How stupid of me. Did you catch this fish yourself?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We found it whole, floating in the swamp. I bet Biaggio he couldn’t eat the whole thing, and it turns out I was right.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Sexy. (points upstairs) And that’s the master bedroom?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. We need the slide because of shit-leg over there. At the table, Patrick inspects the chicken skeleton for m meat.  72. Joe uses this lull to gather the necessary courage.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s also a pretty cool sort of lookout you might like. I dunno. It's sort of splendid. Did I just say “splendid”?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yes, you did. A lookout?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah...we could go check it out of your want. It’s like a fifteen minute hike, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah I want to see everything. But look at this -- I can’t leave Vicki alone with these jackals.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, no. Of course not. INT. HOUSE IN THE WOODS, ‘LIVING ROOM’ - NIGHT Everyone sits on couch cushions that have been tossed on floor. Beers are out. A joint makes the rounds. Some of them wear Patrick’s ridiculous Nigerian bushmen MASKS. They're watching Biaggio, who break dances in the middle the room to “Breathe,” by Prodigy. Biaggio is killing it he’s actually a brilliant dancer. He too wears a mask. Applause. Kelly passes the joint to Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’m good.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Gotcha. (all smiles) No weed, but you’ll run away from home. Very contradictory.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Well, I go back twice a week to do laundry. She smiles.  73.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (holding arm up) I have a beer, see? I’m dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: A full beer. She clanks bottles with him and starts chugging. He does same, catching Joe’s glance across the floor. Patrick rol his eyes, like “women.” Joe fakes a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One side of the fire, Aaron and Vicki. On another, Patric and Kelly. Joe and Biaggio are off to the side, speaking private.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Vicki is making eyes at you. You should go talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: No. I think she likes Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I doubt it. Aaron’s bizarre. I feel like he has no asshole or something. Like a Conehead.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Well, there’s no point in me talking to her anyway. Biaggio looks down.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: (a struggle for him) Joe...I’m gay. Joe is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Jesus...are you sure, man?

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Yes. My lungs fill up with fluid every time the seasons change. Joe thinks about how to put this.  74.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That’s not being gay...I think that means you have cystic fibrosis.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Really? (relief) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. (then) Cystic fibrosis is no walk in the park, Biaggio. Biaggio waves him off, unworried.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: What about her? Joe's POV: Kelly and Patrick, firelit, talking and laughi

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She’s doing what girls do. Acting like she doesn’t care. It’s fine. I can wait. Biaggio leaves to talk to Vicki. Joe watches Kelly, who never looks in his direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downstairs, a tangle of limbs on the floor. And the couch In the dark, we can’t really tell who’s sleeping where.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: Joe lies on his side, covers pulled high. The light is di but we see he’s awake. Creaking from downstairs. The top of the ladder shakes. H stares at it...hands, then arms come into view. Then the face. It’s Kelly. She walks toward Joe. His eyes widen as... She carefully steps over him, and shakes Patrick awake. W don't leave Joe’s face during this next exchange.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (whisper) Hey...can you sleep?  75.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Um, yes. We hear her hushed laughter.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Do you want to take a walk or something? I can’t sleep.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (pause) Sure. We hear rustling; Patrick rises. Tight on Joe. Unblinking EXT. WOODS —- MORNING Wide, expansive. Establish a new day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beams of light slice through the loft. Joe lies in the sa position, wearing the same expression. We hear voices from downstairs. VICKI’S VOICE Is he still sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Joe! Joe doesn’t respond. The ladder rattles; Kelly peeks over the landing. Joe quickly shuts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (whisper) Joe. We’re leaving. Are you awake? Joe keeps his eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelly stands at the edge of the clearing, where the trail begins. Patrick hands her a girlish duffel bag.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: So did Biaggio tell you about “Omerta”?  76.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Omerta, yes. The Sicilian code of silence. Don’t worry, we all swore. He made Aaron cut his palm.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Good. Well, you know the way so +..you can come back anytime.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Thanks. So can you. They both smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car pulls into the driveway...illuminating FRANK on the stoop. Mr. McGuire gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: (emotionless) Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Daniel. Listen, I -- Mr. McGuire punches Frank in the face. Frank goes down.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Nice parenting, you cooze! They roll around on the lawn, fighting. Mrs. McGuire come to the door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: No no no! Nooooo-- Off her howls of protest:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The McGuires sit on their couch, opposite Frank. Frank ho an ice pack to his eye. Mr. McGuire has a scratch mark on his cheek, and a fat lip.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m not here to apologize for my son.  77.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: And you shouldn’t. We don’t even know - for sure - that they ran away. We do not know. All anyone can do is suspect things. Suspect suspect suspect.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: The police have presented a lot of evidence, honey. They’re certain. We have to trust them.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Well what do the police know! With their pig Irish agenda. The Irish are the blacks of Europe! The blacks of Europe!

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: (rubbing her back) Shhhhh...come on. I’m Irish, sweetheart. (then) This has been hard on her, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And I don’t want to take up more of your time. Trust me. I know this is awkward. I just... (pause) I noticed you put some fliers of Patrick around school, around the neighborhood. I asked the police if I should do that with Joe, if that would be helpful, and they said it couldn’t hurt. So I was just going to ask you if you had some pictures of Joseph. If there were shots of him and Patrick together, whatever. Some recent stuff. You’d be doing me a favor. Silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: Oh. I’11 look. We have...hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands Frank about five pictures. Frank thumbs through them.  78. Joe and Patrick on a back porch, drying off, a pool in th background. At Medieval Times, wearing hats. Covered in shaving cream on Halloween. Frank is transfixed by them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SUN. We’re looking straight up at it. Joe lies, squinting, in the same meadow where he picked t flowers for dinner. Utter silence. He twirls a dandelion in his hand... Then grinds the flowerhead between the meaty parts of his thumb and forefinger. Joe sits up. We see that the meadow is expansive, beautif Tall yellow flowers stretch far into the distance. He sha his brow with his hand, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (shouts loudly) Biaggio!? Nothing. He shades his brow, looking for any sign of Biaggio. Then, less than five feet from him, Biaggio emerges, maki Joe jump.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus. Biaggio, when you’re here, keep your head above the surface where I can see you. (rises) I’m going for a walk. Don’t wait up.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: You should try not to think about them so much. Joe hangs his head.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I’m not more fun to be around right now.  79.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Let’s do something fun. You need it. Let’s make fresh jam.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to make fresh jam, Biaggio. I just want to be alone. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Or we could even do that other thing. The thing we talked about.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’m not letting you give me a haircut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe hikes uphill, holding a brown bottle. A ring of sweat around his collar. He pushes through brush, accessing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But finds Patrick and Kelly there. Awkward. Joe fakes a friendly smile.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Oh, hey Joe, I--

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Whoops. No nono nono. Stay here. Do your thing. I’m gonna head back by the house.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What is that? Are you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (waving his hands) Do your thing. Do your thing. I’‘1l see you kids later. Joe leaves. Kelly gets up, but Patrick stops her.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I got it...  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe walks off, no longer smiling, his face red and flush. From behind him:

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Joe. Joe, wait up.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (smiling again) What’s up? Why’d you leave her? Go back.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Joe...look man. Nothing’s going on, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It’s fine. You win. The best man won.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What does that mean? She just likes me. We get along.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Cool. I guess she likes everyone though. So I mean, if she likes everyone, she likes no one. You know? Patrick snatches the bottle from Joe.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this shit... Arizona Iced Tea? You're sober, Joe. Why are you acting like a weird lawyer or something?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You’re so young. (then) Listen, if you and your girlfriend want, come over later for dinner and a board game. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: “Come over”?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If you want. Biaggio will be there too. Good times, good times.  81. Joe stumbles off. Patrick stares after him, bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick and Kelly sit, facing each other.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: We’re not doing anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I know. Patrick looks down, futzing around with a twig, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Do you want to...do something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Very much so. He chucks the twig over the cliff. She approaches and sit in his lap. He puts his arms around her. He’s easily twic her size. They look in the same direction, over the trees

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: So did it work?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Did what work?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: This. The house. Are you happier out here?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I mean...I’m just happy to be where my parents are not.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: They can’t be that bad. I mean what did they do, anyway? Everyone at school thinks they were like molesting the shit out of you.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (laughs) “Molesting the shit out of me”? No no. I would have stayed for that. (she laughs) No...it was nothing that sinister.  82. He thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They weren’t bad people, they were just always...there. Down my throat, all day, every day. Constant and unyielding. I was getting hives. The top of my head would tingle. I thought I was gonna have a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: So, they were down your throat... like everybody else’s parents.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No, “not like everybody else’s.” I do not accept that.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (laughing) Everybody else’s.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’m fourteen. My mom offered to cut my nails six months ago. She sits up, facing him.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Every single morning, my parents set out three dollars and twenty- five cents. The three dollars is for lunch. The twenty five cents is so I can call and tell them I got to school okay. (beat) And I’m fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: They watch me eat. Sometimes they don’t say anything. They get pleasure out of it.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: They watch me sleep. Like serial killers. I wake up, and they’1l be standing at the doorway. Patrick laughs.  83.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's just parents, Patrick. All of them. You have to, like, humor them and get on with your day.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Maybe. EXT. JOE’S HOUSE - DAY Colin packs luggage into his trunk while Frank and Lisa s goodbye. The car idles.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Call me with anything, Dad. Even if it’s bad.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I will. Go to school, get drunk with your friends, do whatever. And you can call me too, you know. They hug. Colin turns and approaches for a goodbye. Frank waves coolly.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Colin. Colin goes in for a handshake, but Frank has already wave Colin quickly retracts, waving, but by then Frank has lea in for a handshake. After a few missed signals, Frank sig grabs Colin’s hand and shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus. It never ends with you. EXT. JOE’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Frank waves as the car pulls away. The car hits the corne and a group of teens, around Joe’s age, ride bikes down t street. Whipping past Frank’s house. Frank watches them g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clicks on the TV, the stereo. Noise fills the atmosphe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonlit. An OWL leaves its perch, gliding over Bringing us to a wide shot of the HOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small thimble lands on CHANCE. Kelly reads a and Patrick face Joe and Biaggio. They all sit

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Ooh -- advance to Indiana. I’1l buy that. Biaggio smashes the floor in anger. He and Joe

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Easy does it. (to them) He likes the red.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: The color of blood. The color of passion.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (to Kelly) I’‘1l give you B&O for both your utilities.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Really? Okay.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: And your Get Out of Jail Free card.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Yeah...but if I need it, can I have it back?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yes, you can have it back.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That’s a smart trade.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: All four railroads for the utilities. Saavy. 84. the trees. card. She on the floor. smoke CIGARS.  85.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: And a Get Out of Jail Free card. Joe rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Just play your game. Don’t worry about us. Tense beat between Joe and Patrick. Kelly’s eyes shift between the friends.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: ...Are you two alright?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (polite smile) We're golden. (rolls die) Monkey. Joe moves his piece to FREE PARKING. Biaggio claps.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Good job, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: He didn’t do anything. It’s dice.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna put one more house on... Joe stops and looks at the board.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually...Biaggio, I will give you Park Place and Baltic, and both my railroads, for both your oranges. Biaggio thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: I want a thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I will give you...a hundred fifty.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Yahtzee. They trade. Patrick shakes his head. This is catastrophic  86.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to Patrick) Property manager, can I get hotels on orange?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You just gave him the corner, dickhead. What’s the matter with you? Patrick puts the hotel on orange...then pauses. He looks his own piece. He’s in jail. A roll away from the oranges Patrick looks at Joe.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s up, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nothing’s up. (big smile) It’s your roll, Tum Tum.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Joe, if I roll a six, eight or nine it’s gonna get very bad in here.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (looking at board) Oh...yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know what to tell you. Think of all the other numbers in the world. Joe leans back and exhales cigar smoke. A woodland Bugsy.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Well let’s just take a minute and relax. It’s a game, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’m relaxed. Biaggio? Biaggio nods, gagging on cigar smoke.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What’s your fucking problem, man??

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Just roll, Patrick. Don’t let it get to you. You'll be fine.  87. A tense moment of silence. Patrick rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide. A beat of nothing...then, the monopoly board flies the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe retreats to the corner. Patrick is trying to move tow him, as Kelly tugs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I have a cigar! Be careful! This whole place is dry wood!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Give a fuck, man! What was that play!?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Jesus! It. Is. A. Game!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What I did was completely legal! Patrick takes a step at Joe, but Kelly steps between them

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You guys, stop! Biaggio’s having some sort of episode! Biaggio sits rocking in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Leave him. He’s rationalizing.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (to Joe) That was the lowest, shittiest, dickhead move I’ve ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Eh -- second lowest. Patrick pauses, marveling at Joe’s pettiness.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Fuck. You. No one was trying to hurt you, man. It had nothing to do with you. Get over it!  88.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’m fucking over it! I don’t care! If the bitch wants you, she’s not good enough for me anyway.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What? Huh?? Who the fuck are you, Mary J. Blige??

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Joe, I didn’t--

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No, Kelly! Everything was fine until you got here. Jesus! You're like a fucking cancer. Kelly is completely stunned. Hurt. Her eyes well up.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Okay. Um, I guess I’ll see you guys later... And just like that...she leaves. Patrick watches.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (hurt, confused) What are you doing, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Go be with her.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go, Joe. Joe pushes him. Patrick doesn’t budge.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Get out of here! Go hang out with Kelly and your goddam mother! Joe keeps pushing him. Patrick stands his ground.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (heartbroken) What...Why are you doing this, man? Then, rage and frustration at their peak, Joe KICKS Patri bad foot. This gets a reaction.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah! Fuck!  89. Patrick’s face darkens. Joe comes to his senses - he just poked the bear.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Shit. Patrick raises his hand to punch Joe, but resists the urg he'd kill him. He turns, channeling his rage toward the A HOCKEY TABLE. He chucks it, roaring, in Joe’s general direction. It hits the WEST WALL and topples it. Leaves a dirt kick up, blowing into the house. Joe watches, his chest heaving with anger, panic. Then he turns to Patrick. They look at each other. Silence. There has never been such darkness between them. Finally, inevitably...Patrick moves to the door. Joe watc him leave. It’s over. Biaggio approaches Joe, meek.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just leave me alone, please.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’m saying leave. Get out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Be straight with me, Joe. Tell me what’s on your mind Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I want to be alone, Biaggio. Get the fuck out.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Don’t mince words with me, Joe. We've been through too much. Joe looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biaggio walks out in a wide shot. His head hangs.  90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits on the sofa, back to the downed wall, taking in ruin of his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various shots of Patrick, struggling on his bad foot, thr brush and over huge, gangly roots. He uses a large branch a WALKING STICK. He sits on a rock, massaging his lower leg. Angry. Sad. It's all hitting him.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Fucking Joe. Asshole. Suddenly, we hear a RUSTLE. Patrick looks up.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is someone there? Kelly? A shadowy figure wipes across the foreground. We can’t ma it out.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Biaggio, you're smarter than this. We hear a GRUNT. It’s not Biaggio. Patrick rises, moving down the path as quickly as his bum foot will allow. Then, a TUFT OF ORANGE HAIR catches his eye. What is happening? Patrick limps faster now, panicking, out of breath. A snarling ROAR.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to himself) Oh fuck. God. Jesus. FOOTSTEPS. Whatever it is, it’s getting closer. Patrick STUMBLES on a root, and falls against a tree. He turns, hiding behind it.  91. Patrick takes his sneaker off, jamming the walking stick inside it to simulate a leg. He sticks it out into the pa as bait. Nothing bites. Silence. He turns to look at the path. It’s empty. As he doubles back behind the tree: We reveal a huge, green 2-D computer-animated monster -- BLANKA from “Street Fighter.” Standing on hind legs, it ROARS 3 TIMES in Patrick’s face Patrick SCREAMS and, instinctively, SMASHES BLANKA IN THE FACE with his walking stick. Upon impact, Blanka transforms into what he actually is - small tree with a shock of red-orange leaves at the top. Patrick has cracked it in half.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Huh. He stares at it, his head cocked. He blinks. Just a tree. Nothing scary about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelly, walking on a dark street. Alone. Unhappy. We hear the clacking of her shoes. Then from behind her:

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Kelly! She stops. He limps/runs toward her, catching up. They stand face to face for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (blurting) I didn't want any of this to happen I don’t want to come between friends I've just liked you for months and I figured if I came out here and we got to-- He kisses her. She returns it.  92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe tries to lift the fallen wall. He’s not strong enough He gives up, looks at it, rubs his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe picks bits of meat from a clean chicken skeleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank opens the refrigerator door. The only option: lefto shrimp with lobster sauce. Christ knows how old it is. Quick cuts: He picks the shrimp out and places them over some white r Pops the bowl in the microwave. Eats in front of the television. INT. FRANK’S ROOM - NIGHT Frank, alone in a king-size bed, staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe pulls the sheets up to his chin. He rolls over, tryin to get comfortable. Sounds of the forest occasionally startle him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extreme wide. The house, a small and vulnerable structure the huge, dark forest. INT. PATRICK’S ROOM - MORNING Patrick wakes up. In his own bed. He rolls over: His parents are watching from the doorway. Disbelieving. Overcome.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCGUIRE
dialogues.text: We didn’t want to wake you.  93.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You were watching me sleep. He smiles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilt down from the sky to a festive SMALL TOWN PARADE. Families, teenagers, the elderly, all line the curb. Marching down the street: attractive women in red, white blue leotards. Members of the local Chamber of Commerce i behind the twirlers in a vintage Cadillac. Banners read “HAPPY MEMORIAL DAY.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of college-age kids, set back from the crowd, sit around an SUV, drinking, grilling. An adorable, long-legged girl in sparkle-y FACE PAINT (21 makes eyes at... A dangerous looking guy in a VISOR (26), standing way in corner, with his back to the WOODS. He takes a sip of bee She looks away. Then looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make out against a tree. The parade isn’t too far aw we can still hear faint music, applause.

dialogues.speaker: VISOR
dialogues.text: (takes her hand) Come on.

dialogues.speaker: FACE PAINT
dialogues.text: Where are we going? He leads her deeper into the woods. They pause every few trees to kiss some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoes, flip-flops come off. Unzipping; they are both stepping on their shorts, prying them off their ankles. Breaking the kiss, he takes her shirt off, chucks it.

dialogues.speaker: VISOR
dialogues.text: Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: FACE PAINT
dialogues.text: Wait wait wait. Hold on. She dips her toe in, testing. He grabs her, pulls her clo more kissing, kinda sloppy. As they pull apart, a shape emerges drifts on the water behind them trees behind them JOE. Asleep in the tire. Looking like shit, sun-blasted, filthy and too thin. They see him.

dialogues.speaker: FACE PAINT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ohmigod! Joe wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (groggy) Wha...? Pat--oh, Jesus-- Joe averts his eyes. The girl grabs her shirt, looking to cover up quickly.

dialogues.speaker: VISOR
dialogues.text: Kid! What the fuck man! He and her dart off into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Sorry... They’re gone. Joe looks at the empty spot where they disappeared into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe wanders, tossing twigs around, aimless. Stumbling abo like a man who’s been in the desert for days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe jams flint against a twig, into a pile of dry sticks leaves. He’s awkward, sometimes missing the twig entirely It’s not working.  95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the cooler. Scraps of odd, unidentifiable meat. Four berries in the bottom of a basket. A rotten apple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overcome by hunger, he closes his eyes and eats a bunch o PURPLE BERRIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide. Joe VOMITS some purple stuff into the stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe looks in the petty cash box. Just some change. Not ev quarters.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frenetic camera. Joe searches the pockets of his shorts, pants, everything he brought with him. He pulls the pocke inside out. Two nickels in one. The rest are empty. His expression grows dire. In one of the pockets, we hear the crisp rustle of money he pulls something from a pocket, but it’s not cash: it’s old Boston Market order, scribbled onto a torn sheet of paper. Shit. He chucks it aside. He dumps out the contents of his DUFFEL BAG. Rummages through the pile. Beneath some junky housewares, he unexpectedly finds... The library books. Still unopened. “WALDEN.”...”105 OUTDO RECIPES”...”“SO YOU WANT TO BUILD A CABIN”... And most appropriately: “I’D RATHER BE HUNTING.” Joe regards it with curiosity...  96. CAPT. DAVIS’S VOICE From a statement given by Patrick McGuire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits across from CAPTAIN ARTY DAVIS (45). Frank lea against the wall behind them, watching. The Captain reads from a file.

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DAVIS
dialogues.text: “May 12th. We had a fight. Over something stupid, but...you know. It got out of hand. I came home; there was no point in going on if we were fighting. (then) The destination was Tallahassee. It was Joe’s choice, he told me he liked the word, liked that it had three double-letters.”

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hm. Seems arbitrary.

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DAVIS
dialogues.text: (nodding) Patrick continues: “I don’t pretend to understand the guy. I just want him to be okay. Let me know what you find out.” Davis closes the file. Frank frowns.

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know. But I looked in his eyes, Mr. Toy. He was telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And the other kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and the Captain look through a two-way mirror: Biag stands next to a chair, across from two seated COPS.

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DAVIS
dialogues.text: Biaggio Verga. McGuire says he was with them the whole time. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m afraid he’s given us nothing so far...he has a contempt for the law I’ve never seen in a minor. The captain presses a speaker button on a console. We hea the conversation in the interrogation room.

dialogues.speaker: COP 1
dialogues.text: Why don’t you sit down so we can have a nice discussion. We’re all pals, right? No reason not to be.

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DAVIS
dialogues.text: (to Frank) He won’t sit. Won’t deflate the room. It’s actually very sophisticated. Biaggio walks to the two-way mirror and stares through it He knows he’s being watched.

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This kid is in my head. Biaggio returns to the chair, picks it up and walks calml toward the glass. The two cops quickly move toward him.

dialogues.speaker: COP 1
dialogues.text: Whoa whoa whoa. None of that. They wrestle the chair from him.

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DAVIS
dialogues.text: He knows something. Maybe a lot. Frank stares at Biaggio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide. To establish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A EUROPEAN STARLING steps gingerly toward a pile of appetizing berries. Reaching down to PECK, the ground suddenly collapses bene it. It disappears into a hole. We hear sounds of distress Joe jumps out from behind a tree, holding his SWORD. He charges the hole, upon it in less than a second.  98.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Bah! Murder! Murder! Murder! He stabs downward until we hear no more sounds of distres Joe pants, falls to his knees, rattled.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were just hungry...we’re all hungry.... (then) I’m sorry I yelled at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, referring to an open book, rhythmically moves the fl downward against the dry wood until he gets a spark. He stares at it, shocked...then remembers to BLOW. FIRE. On Joe: amazed at the fire, and at himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stands over a pot of steaming water, holding the star out in front of him. He’s full of grime and bird blood.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Goddam it... He drops the bird in, averting his eyes. The water bubble sizzles, hisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe yanks feathers from the bird. Wings, then neck. We ca tell he’s not happy about it, but it has to be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carcass is laid out on a rock, next to a reference bo Joe holds a machete.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (reading) “Gut bird, slicing vertically from rectum to collar. Save the heart, liver and gizzard if you wish.” (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to book) Go fuck yourself. He scrunches up his face and makes an incision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe wipes his hands with a rag looking down at something: A nicely cooked STARLING, still whole, on a platter. Soot marks and stab wounds aside, it’s an appetizing sight. Joe scatters some berries into the plate beside the bird, the sake of aesthetics... Then places a single green HERB on top. He sits down, stares at his preparation. He does not smil instead, he looks at the empty chairs around the table. He sighs... Then looks past the chairs, squinting. Joe's POV: Patrick’s BUSHMAN MASK hangs by the door. Star at him. Off Joe's face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe pulls his chair up again, nodding across the table. Reverse to: The MASK, a lousy rendition of Patrick, hangs from the to the chair. It stares back at Joe. Joe starts eating. He opens his mouth to speak...then clo it...then opens it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Wha...I...Um... (comes to his senses) Yeah. Joe stares at the mask for a sad beat, then returns to hi meal. Suddenly - oddly - the mask chair SHIFTS. Joe stops chewi and smiles. A fleeting moment of delusion.  100.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-Hello? The chair shifts again. Not much, an inch or two. But the movement is obvious. Joe’s smile disappears -- something isn’t right. He pushes his chair back, slowly ducking under the table. and finds

dialogues.speaker: THE COPPERHEAD
dialogues.text: Moving quickly toward his legs. Joe collapses out of his chair, terrified. The snake BITE but is still too far away to connect with Joe. Joe regains his footing and runs to the center of the roo It moves toward him, sizing him up, HISSING... Joe takes two steps back, and the snake quickly covers th ground. A beat on Joe, looking around, gaging his distance to the door, versus where the snake is. He will lose that race. The snake is only a few feet away, approaching tentativel Joe is cornered. Last option: Joe takes a deep breath, and STANDS HIS GROUND. The snake pauses. Joe closes his eyes, and puts his hand on his chest. He exhales slowly. Tries to relax. When he opens his eyes... The snake has re-coiled. It, too, is relaxed. Its tongue flicks out every two seconds. Rhythmic. In sync with Joe' breathing. Totally calm, Joe sits Indian-style across from the snake His eyes never leave it. EXT. BIAGGIO’S STREET - DAY To establish. INT. BIAGGIO’S ROOM - DAY Biaggio kneels by his bed, head bowed. He holds ROSARY BE  101. INT. BIAGGIO’S KITCHEN - DAY Biaggio enters. His FATHER sits at the table, shucking clams. The following dialogue is in Italian, subtitled.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Sit. He pushes a bowl of closed clams toward Biaggio, and hand him a shucking knife. Biaggio goes to work.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Have you ever quit at anything?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: +.-and did it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Well, there’s good quitting and bad quitting. I quit drinking soda: good quitting. I quit law school: bad quitting. Do you see?

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Yes. (then) Did you ever quit on a friend?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: You should never quit on a friend, Biaggio.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: But say you did. Say you abandoned him, left him alone even after you swore your allegiance...would you go to hell for that?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Of course. Biaggio nods. He already knew this.  102. EXT. BIAGGIO’S HOUSE - DAY Long lens. Biaggio walks outside, and into his yard. Pull back to reveal a REARVIEW MIRROR in the foreground... We’re watching from Frank’s car. Biaggio blasts out of hi backyard on a bicycle. Frank shifts into gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biaggio parks dismounts, and walks it into the woods. Onc Biaggio has wiped frame, reveal Frank’s car PULLING UP in background...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biaggio emerges from the path, sighs with relief at the s of the house. Biaggio’s POV: The house looks better than ever. Refinished. Fire burning. The colors seem more vibrant, the angles of incident more square.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Kid, what the fuck is this. Biaggio turns around; his eyes could not be wider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Joe’s face: Asleep, slumped against the wall. In the s clothes as the last time we saw him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: How long? The whole time?? Joe startles AWAKE. BIAGGIO’S VOICE Omerta. The Sicilian code of silence.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: No! No Omerta! Widen out: He’s sitting on the floor, as he was when the snake was there...but there’s no snake.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Dad! Don’t come in! Seriously!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's over Joe! It’s the end of the world! Frank barges through the door, holding Biaggio.

dialogues.speaker: JOE FRANK
dialogues.text: Dad, I mean it! There’s a Bullshit, Joe! Start snake in here-- explaining. From the beginning. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Infamata. The serpent is COILED AT BIAGGIO’S FEET. Staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Whoa...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (hushed) Biaggio. Be still. Be calm.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: I’m going to run. I feel that I have to.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Biaggio, do not run. A beat of tension. WE hear hissing. Then...Biaggio runs.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: shit-- The snake is upon him instantly. Biaggio trips over himse and falls into the corner. Biaggio’s POV: the copperhead, coming straight for him. He SCREAMS. It bites him in the CHEEK. On Joe: horror.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (nauseous ) Oh. Oh my fucking Christ. Biaggio faints.  104. The snake turns toward Frank, and Frank immediately break into a run.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Dad! No-- Frank throws furniture and debris, trying to deter it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The fuck is wrong with this thing?! The snake is upon him. Frank braces himself... Suddenly, JOE’S SHOE pins the snake to the floor, landing just beneath its head. It can’t move, can’t bite. A mache enters frame, decapitating it. Snake blood everywhere. Joe drops the machete, panting. A shaken hero.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joe... They stare at each other, overwhelmed. Then: BIAGGIO’S VOICE Hello. Of course, Biaggio. They rush to him; he’s flush, breathi heavy. Bleeding from the puncture wounds in his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Did it get me?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: A little bit. (to Frank) Dad, bury the head and body outside in two separate holes. The loose venom can attract other ones. But Frank doesn’t move. He still has so many questions.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, Dad. Joe moves to the cooler.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Very different.  105. Joe hands him a plastic bag holding a bloody cut of raw m

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Here. You need protein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank scoops dirt over the snake’s body. He emits various sounds of disgust. Joe and Biaggio appear in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to Frank) We've got fifteen minutes. Did you drive here?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah..(seeing something) Whoa...hey hey hey-- He points to a dark stain growing on Biaggio’s pants.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Biaggio!

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’re pissing yourself, kid! Biaggio looks down - it’s true.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: I can’t feel it. I can’t feel anything down there... Biaggio’s knees buckle. He VOMITS.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Shit. Systems are failing. Biaggio’s nose begin to run.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: (out of it) I’m open. I’m open now, Joe. The snake opened me... Sweat, pooling at Biaggio’s collar bone. His eyes tear up Everything’s leaving him.  106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biaggio crawls to the sofa. Joe helps him over, rubs his back.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Let it all out. (to Frank) Can you pull the car up to here??

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Impossible...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to Biaggio) Hey -- do you feel up to a little walk, buddy? Biaggio closes his eyes and pisses himself again.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He’s really...he can’t hold it, huh.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You’ve gotta carry him, Dad. Frank grimaces at Biaggio, who is soaked in himself.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, he will die.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Joe, come over here. Come here. Joe walks over.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, we could carry him. We could drive him to the hospital and hope for the best. We could put him through all that. Or we could just choose to remember him as he was.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: JUMP CUT TO
dialogues.text: Frank lifts Biaggio off the sofa, across his shoulders. H flares his nostrils, nauseated.  107.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ah fuck. He smells like vinegar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank carries Biaggio through the woods. Joe runs just ah of them. Biaggio bumps around, moaning. It’s not a happy time in his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Biaggio in the backseat. Frank speeds, slaloming through traffic. The windows are open.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Keep him awake, Joe! Keep him talking!

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: (weak) Wash me...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He keeps asking me to wash him!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Godammit Biaggio! We can’t wash you! We don’t have the tools!

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Clean my skin. Make my skin clean. Frank's POV - he blows through a yellow that just turned The camera flashes. He will get a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Fuck. In the backseat:

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: I’m open, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I know buddy. I know you’re open.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Joe...what if I start to do other things, Joe?  Joe looks 108.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What are “other things”?

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Other things. Ass things.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Ass things...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What’s he saying? He gonna shit the car??

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: I don’t want to shit the car.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: None of us want that. We’re all on the same team here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You_gotta fight this thing, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Just don’t think about it. Keep talking to me. Just talk. We’re almost there and then you'll get medicine and the pain will stop.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: (at death’s door) Joe...I’m sorry...I’m sorry I led him here...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's okay man. You didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: I didn’t know...I’m not...I would never betray you...I’m not like Patrick...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah... out the window. A beat of sadness.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Biaggio, do you-- But something’s wrong. Biaggio’s eyes are CLOSED, his mou foaming.  109.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh God. Oh Jesus. His mouth, Dad! He’s foaming at the mouth!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Uh...That’s good! That means his body's fighting it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Biaggio! Fuck! Dad, he’s dead!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (truly worried) Okay, we’re here. We’re here Joe. It’s out of our hands. Just, I don’t know. Pray for him. They SWERVE into the hospital parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank rushes Biaggio in. Joe waves at a nurse for attenti She takes Biaggio. Doctors arrive. A stretcher. Medical chaos ensues. Joe and Frank watch, concerned, helpless. We FADE TO WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe washes his face. A knock on the door. Joe opens it; Frank in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Try these. Frank hands him a bag from the hospital gift shop. Quick cuts: Joe brushes his teeth He puts on deodorant. He looks at himself in the mirror, shirtless, slaps his exposed rib cage once. Joe puts on a fresh $4 T-shirt. It says “NYC.”  110. Joe regards a razor...looks at his moustache...puts the r back in the bag. He owns the moustache now. INT. HOSPITAL, BIAGGIO’S ROOM - NIGHT Biaggio sits up in bed. He eats from a small plastic container of apple sauce.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You honestly believe you saw heaven? Biaggio nods.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Yes. Joe...I saw your mother.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: My mother’s still alive.

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: Oh. Then maybe it was my mother. Suddenly, VICKI enters.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Look at you! Then, right behind her...KELLY. And PATRICK. Joe tenses up. This is the first time we’ve seen Patrick ‘back.’ He looks good, put some weight back on. Haircut. Pressed shirt. Joe and Patrick see each other, then look away.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Are you okay, Biaggio?

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: I am. My body is healing. Some have suggested it wasn’t my time.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah -- you’re fourteen man.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Joe, are you hurt? Joe shakes his head “no.” Awkwardness in the room.  111.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: (at Biaggio’s bandage) Is that where it bit you?

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: My God...what did it feel like?

dialogues.speaker: BIAGGIO
dialogues.text: It felt like, when you’re expecting great pain, and then it happens. As the girls question Biaggio, Joe and Patrick make, then retract, eye contact. They have no idea how to be around each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe eats a slice of pizza. Two more pizza crusts litter h plate. There’s also an empty bowl of nachos. We see the cafeteria is virtually empty except for Joe an Frank watches his son eat. As Joe finishes, Frank pushes own plate of spaghetti toward Joe.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: How long was Biaggio dead?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Six minutes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (unimpressed) Six minutes? Oh.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That’s a long time to be dead, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Not in the scheme of things. (then) You...uh...you did a good job, Joe. You did a good job back there.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: A good job?  112.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You saved my life. You saved Biaggio’s life. I dunno. A lesser man would have panicked.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks. A beat between father and son.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Are you still hungry? What do you want. Anything.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Honestly? I would love seafood.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hm. Frank looks around at the shitty hospital food court.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know if this is the best place for that. (then) They have churros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe eats a churro.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Not bad, right? Joe shakes his head. Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (carefully) We can do seafood tomorrow. plan on being around. If you

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I should be. Frank nods. Relief.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: So who's that girl Patrick was with? He’s got a girlfriend, huh?  113.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Looks that way.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Good for him. What are you guys, fourteen? (then) If you think parents and school and all this shit is stressful, wait until you start carving the Ham.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The Ham. Like, the Ham?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, like HAMphibian. HAMbush.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You know about the Ham?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean...I thought it was common. Isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No, I guess it must be. Huh. (then) I thought I was alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Frank wait by the elevator. The down arrow DINGS. The doors open. Patrick, his parents, and Kelly are inside. Joe and Frank enter. A nurse wheels an elderly patient in with them. Doors close on the packed elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone stands in silence. We hear only the wet, rattlin breath of the elderly patient. INT/EXT. FRANK’S CAR - NIGHT Frank and Joe drive. Joe looks out the window at his neighborhood. Then the McGuire family car pulls up alongside them, pass them. Patrick and Kelly in the backseat.  114. They stop at a red light. Joe glances over; he’s in line with Patrick, who isn’t looking. Then, Patrick looks. Joe immediately turns away. He turns back; now Patrick turns away. Joe leans back. Staring ahead. He glances over, subtly, trying not to move his head, and sees Patrick smiling and shaking his head. Joe looks over. Finally, he smiles too. Joe shoots Patrick the finger. Patrick nods and returns i Joe gestures behind Patrick toward Kelly. He inserts his pointer finger into the end of his fist, then raises his eyebrows inquisitively. Patrick laughs, shakes his head no. Joe then places his hands on his chest. A new question. Patrick shrugs and smiles coyly. Joe's eyes widen. Really? Patrick shrugs again, with a big shit-eating grin. Joe laughs. The light changes. Joe’s car starts to inch up. They’re losing sight of each other. Frank senses the activity.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What’s going on over there?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (facing forward again) Nothing. Patrick’s being an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide, looking down at the intersection. Patrick’s car tak a right, while Joe’s continues straight. As the cars disappear, we tilt up, over the rooftops, toward the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: END CREDITS ROLL over a wide shot of the house. The fores teems around it. Animals wander in and out, confused. Lig shifts as hours pass. In time, the sun sets on the empty house, though the fire still burns. THE END.
